revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Rogozarski aircraft to [[:Category:Rogožarski aircraft]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text: {|{{Infobox Aircraft Begin | name=Rogožarski PVT | image=Rogozarski PVT-H1.JPG | caption= }}{{Infobox Aircraft Type | type=[[Trainer (aircraft)|Advanced trainer]] | national origin=[[Kingdom of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]] | manufacturer=[[Rogožarski]], Belgrade | designer= R. Fizir; [[Sima Milutinović - Aircraft constructor|Sima Milutinović]]; K. Sivčev and A.Biščević | first flight=c.1934 | introduced=1936 | retired=1945 | status=inactive | primary user=[[Yugoslav Royal Air Force]] | more users= | produced= | number built=61Петровић, O. (2004). Војни аероплани Краљевине СХС/Југославије (Део II: 1931–1941.). Београд: МВЈ Лет 3. | program cost= | unit cost= | developed from= | variants with their own articles= }} |} The '''Rogožarski PVT''' ({{lang-sr-Cyrl|Рогожарски ПВТ}}; transliterated as Rogozarski PWT in German and as Rogojarsky PVT in some older English sources) was a single-engined, two-seat [[parasol wing]]ed aircraft designed as an advanced and fighter [[Trainer (aircraft)|trainer]] in [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]] before World War II. Over 60 were built, serving with the [[Yugoslav Royal Air Force]] (YAF) until the fall of Yugoslavia in 1941. After that, some PVTs were used by the newly formed [[Air Force of the Independent State of Croatia]], sometimes as ground attack aircraft. ==Design and development== The ''Prva Srpska Fabrika Aeroplana Živojin [[Rogožarski]]'' was the first [[Serbia]]n aircraft manufacturer in [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]], founded in 1924. In about 1933 its team of Rudolf Fizir, [[Sima Milutinović]], Kosta Sivčev and Adem Biščević designed the PVT, a training aircraft with tandem open cockpits in an oval wooden monocoque fuselage. Its wooden, canvas covered wings were swept and [[Parasol wing|parasol]] mounted well above the fuselage with pairs of lift struts to the lower fuselage and a central inverted V [[Cabane strut|cabane]]. They carried long narrow chord ailerons, with prominent [[Aileron#Spades|spades]] well clear of the upper surfaces.{{harvnb|Grey|1938|page=314–5c}} The PVT was powered by a 420 hp (313 kW) 7-cylinder radial [[Gnome-Rhône 7K]] [[radial engine]], housed with its cylinder heads exposed and driving a two-bladed [[propeller (aircraft)|propeller]]. The fixed, divided type undercarriage had on each side a main shock absorber leg, its upper end attached to a steel pyramid protruding from the mid-fuselage keeping the leg closer to the vertical whilst providing a wide track. Each wheel was connected to the lower fuselage with a swinging V-strut. A simple tail skid completed the undercarriage. The horizontal tail and fixed fin were both canvas covered wooden structures, though the moving surfaces, also canvas covered, had metal frames. The tailplane was strut braced to the fuselage from below and wire braced above to the fin. It carried elevators which were spade assisted like the ailerons but also horn balanced. The unbalanced rudder was broad and rounded. ==Operational history== The PVT prototype probably first flew in 1934. An initial production batch of 20 aircraft was delivered to the YAF during 1936.[http://www.aeroflight.co.uk/waf/yugo/jkrv/types/rog_pvt.htm Aeroflight: Rogosarski PVT] Another 40 were delivered during 1938-9, of which the last 10 had fixed 7.7 mm (0.303 in) forward firing machine guns fitted and were powered by a licence built version of the Gnôme-Rhône 7K engine, the IAM K7.{{harvnb|Grey|1938|page=42d}} More PVTs were under construction at the time of the [[Invasion of Yugoslavia|Italo-German invasion of Yugoslavia]] in April 1941. Fifteen PVTs captured by the Germans as a result were presented to the newly formed [[Croatian Air Force (Independent State of Croatia)|Air Force of the Independent State of Croatia]]. Later some of these were fitted with bomb racks and used as attack aircraft until 1945. A few PVTs, designated '''PVT-H''', (the H from ''hidro'') were configured as seaplanes on standard [[EDO Corporation|Edo]] (EDO Float Model 38) floats mounted on N-shaped struts. During 1938 and 1939, four PVT-H aircraft were delivered to the [[Yugoslav Royal Navy]].Janić, Čedomir (7.01.1983.). "Akrobatski Hidroavion" (in (Serbian)). Front (-{YU}--Београд: Narodna armija) 1276. ==Operators== ;{{flag|Kingdom of Yugoslavia}} *[[Royal Yugoslav Air Force]] 61 aircraft *[[Yugoslav Royal Navy]] ;{{flagcountry|Independent State of
